[NUMBERED_ITEM] The  $\gamma \delta$  receptor is the first TCR to be expressed during fetal life.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] $\gamma \delta$ - and  $\alpha \beta$ -expressing thymocytes are separate lineages originated from a common precursor
The ultimate goal of selection in the thymus is to produce T cells that are
Self-MHC restricted to recognize foreign antigenic peptides with self-MHC (positive selection)
Self tolerant not to respond to self-peptides (negative selection)
SP: Single Positive CD4 SP (CD4⁺CD8⁻) CD8 SP (CD8⁺CD4⁻) (10 %)
[H1] Death of immature thymocytes in the thymus by apoptosis.
A mechanism of cell death in which the cells to be killed are induced to degrade themselves from within, in a tidy manner
The death of cells by lysis that results from chemical or physical injury. It leaves extensive cellular debris that must be removed by phagocytes.
[H1] Positive and negative selection of T cells.
To generate T cells that can recognize foreign or non-self antigens in the context of self MHC (self-MHC restricted)
To eliminate potentially self-reactive T cells that recognize self peptide-MHC complexes (tolerized)
Where in the thymus do T cells undergo selection processes?
[H1] Development of T cells in the thymus.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Cell type: cells residing in the thymus
[H1] Positive selection of T cells and MHC.
To generate T cells that can discriminate foreign-peptides from self-peptides in the context of self-MHC (MHC restricted)
An applicant who wants to be a soldier
Learn to distinguish allies from enemies
Will be kicked out, if s/he is rebellious or hopeless
A T cell with too strong or too weak avidity dies

Cells that can express MHC class II
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Cell type: cells residing in the thymus
If T cells escape from selection processes in the thymus, what would be the consequences?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Failure of positive selection; Lack of functional T cells
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Failure of negative selection; Self-reactive T cells in the periphery resulting in autoimmunity
The ultimate goal of selection is to produce T cells that are
[LIST_ITEM] Self-MHC restricted to recognize foreign antigenic peptides with self-MHC AND
[LIST_ITEM] Self tolerant not to respond to self-peptides
Highly personalized as a result of positive and negative selection
This is due to the diversity of HLA types in the human population.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What do T cells require to become mature T cells in the thymus?
CD4 T cells require MHC class II-peptide complexes expressed on thymic stromal cells.
CD8 T cells require MHC class I-peptide complexes expressed on thymic stromal cells.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the developmental pathway of thymocytes?
DP (CD4⁺CD8⁺); intermediate stage and the most abundant population of thymocytes
SP (CD4⁺ or CD8⁺); matured and exit to the periphey
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is positive and negative selection of T cells?
Positive selection: T cells bearing TCR that are partially signaled by self-MHC with peptides are rescued from apoptosis and matures.
Negative selection: T cells recognizing self-peptide bound to self-MHC with high affinity are deleted by apoptosis.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Why is T cell selection important?
To generate T cells that are not self-reactive (tolerant) and recognize foreign peptides with self-MHC.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the consequence of dysregulated T cell development?
Lack of functional T cells (immunodeficiencies) or production of autoreactive T cells (autoimmune diseases)
[H1] Why does an individual express a limited number of different MHC molecules?
A T cell repertoire of an individual is diverse enough to mediate a whole array of different immune reactions.
How can we achieve the diversity of T cells with a limited number of HLA?
A possible maximum number of peptides that can be bound by one MHC allele
[LIST_ITEM] Let’s take MHC class I that binds a 9 aa long peptide
[LIST_ITEM] Each position can have 20 different amino acid residues
Total peptides presentable by one MHC allele
[LIST_ITEM] Anchor residues; Both the position and identity restriction
[LIST_ITEM] A smaller number of total MHC-peptide complexes
What would happen to the T cell repertoire, if you have a defect in the following molecules?
MHC class I MHC class II β2m TAP Ii
[H1] Phenotype of the T cell repertoire.
Any defect in proper expression of MHC class I on the cell surface → No CD8 T cells
Any defect in proper expression of MHC class II expression on the cell surface → No CD4 T cells
